game.name: 264 - 7th Saga, The (USA)
game.info: 7th Saga is a SNES jRPG notorious for its unforgiving difficulty in that monsters are brutally difficult and the heroes’ stats don’t rise particularly generously with their levels. It is not widely known, however, that 7th Saga is the localized version of Elnard, the Japanese incarnation of this game which is much, much easier by comparison. This IPS patch restores the monster stats of Elnard to the US 7th Saga and also modifies the mechanics of player leveling such that the player will now gain stats as he or she would in Elnard, making the game’s difficulty level much more reasonable. Additionally, confrontations with the rival apprentices in this game are now properly balanced, an oversight in the localized version.

game.name: 2647 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: If a Condemned character Jumps, and their countdown reaches 0 while they are in mid-air, they will be subject to Doom, but the Wound status they receive will be replaced by Air Anchor status which will only kill them on the ground, just so they have a chance to land. However, their HP will still be 0, so if the battle ends while they are still in the air, they will technically still be alive afterward, but will have 0 HP. This patch ensures that if a battle ends with a character in this state, they will receive Wound status and be counted out of receiving EXP and Magic Points as normal.

game.name: 2648 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: This patch fixes a game-breaking bug that is triggered when the player dies 52 times in a row on the world map. The reason for this is that the Game Over event script calls an event that causes the player to exit the current location, which is the blank map for the Game Over screen; this script is the only script that calls the event. However, a side effect of this exit event is that the subsequent event, a return statement, never gets called.

game.name: 265 - Final Fantasy II (USA)
game.info: The Warp/Degeon spell in FF4 has an animation, palette, and sound effect even though the spell is not normally usable in battle. Previously the only way to see this animation was to give the caster Wall/Reflect status and reflect the spell onto an enemy, however this would not use the correct palette. This patch makes Warp into an instant death spell, which in addition to being very useful early in the game allows you to see the animation.

game.name: 2650 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: When Celes meets Edgar–sorry, Gerad–in Nikeah, Sabin may be with her. Edgar claims to not know either of them, which ticks off Celes, and should especially tick off Sabin. There’s even a line of dialogue in the game that is appropriate here, but was never used for some reason. If this patch is applied, it will be used if Sabin is in the party.

game.name: 2652 - Bust-A-Move (USA)
game.info: Bust-M-Up is a hack made for the SNES version of Bust-A-Move. Do not use this patch with a Puzzle Bobble ROM. Even though they appear to be the same game, there are minor differences which will render the patch useless given the wrong game. Easiest way to tell if you’ve got the right ROM is to open it up and read the title screen. Anyway…

game.name: 2656 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: Did you know that there’s a hidden Chocobo Stable near Figaro Castle? That means you can walk to it from Narshe, which is where you’ll be during Banon’s scenario (though why you’d want to is beyond me). If Banon’s the lead character, he’ll be seen riding out of the stable…then transforming into Esper Terra repeatedly since he doesn’t actually have a riding sprite. He’ll also look messed up once you get to the world map. This patch fixes both of these issues.

game.name: 2658 - Super Mario World 2 - Yoshi's Island (USA)
game.info: This is a simple hack that mutes Baby Mario’s crying and the timer countdown sound that normally plays when Yoshi is hit and loses Baby Mario.

game.name: 2659 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: There is a bug called the “Psycho Cyan Bug” which is the result of two bugs. One of these bugs causes Cyan to counter the first physical attack by anyone against anyone with Retort if he is defeated and then revived after preparing Retort; there is already a patch that fixes this. The other bug causes Cyan to counter any physical attack against him if he is transformed into an Imp after preparing Retort, because an Imp will Fight instead of using Retort, and thus the game does not realize that Retort was used. The combination of these two bugs causes Cyan to attack repeatedly until the battle ends. This patch fixes the second of the two bugs.

game.name: 2672 - Mega Man X2 (USA)
game.info: This patch adds support for CD quality audio to Mega Man X2 using MSU-1 chip invented by byuu. So far, it is only supported and tested on bsnes, higan and the SD2SNES flashcart.

game.name: 2693 - Super Metroid (Japan, USA) (En,Ja)
game.info: The Story: At the end of the known galactic systems, lies an abandoned planet for the civilization that was there, now is extinct… Called “Lost World”, this planet is still wild and nature has grown free from dominate species, pollution or whatever could modified it…

game.name: 2697 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: In this hack, Mario only has 100 seconds (or less) to beat the level!

game.name: 2705 - Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles IV - Turtles in Time (USA)
game.description: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles IV - Turtles in Time (USA)
game.info: This patch adds support for CD quality audio to Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles IV: Turtles in Time using MSU-1 chip invented by byuu. So far, it is only supported and tested on bsnes, higan and the SD2SNES flashcart.

patch.name: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles IV - Turtles in Time (USA).ips

rom.name: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles IV - Turtles in Time (USA).sfc

game.name: 2713 - Seiken Densetsu 3 (Japan)
game.info: Seiken Densetsu 3 / Secret of Mana 2 - Icon Patches v1.00 [January 23, 2016]

game.name: 2736 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: If Celes (or Gogo) absorbs the Vanish spell via the Runic ability, they will not gain the Vanish status. Despite this, they will still be subject to Vanish’s gradual disappearance animation and then reappear in the same manner. This patch ensures that they do not disappear or reappear.

game.name: 2739 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: If a character wearing Magitek Armor has the Vanish status, the “wipe-down” effect of them disappearing will include their legs and thus their outline will be drawn outside the armor. If the status is removed in battle, the re-appearance effect will also include their legs. This patch fixes both of those problems.

game.name: 2745 - Zombies Ate My Neighbors (USA)
game.info: A complete new hack of the Super Nintendo game Zombies Ate My Neighbors, after over 3 years of working on and off regarding it, I finally feel like it is solid! All 55 levels are completely re-made and reverse cycling and random starting items are implemented.

game.name: 2755 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The damage algorithm for Setzer’s Dice weapons inflicts damage equal to twice his Level times the product of his dice rolls. There’s also a matching bonus that applies if all dice show the same number: the damage will be multiplied by that number. This bonus was intended for both of his Dice weapons; however, it only applies to the Fixed Dice. Depending on which patch you apply, you can ensure that the regular Dice will also receive a matching bonus.

game.name: 2756 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The Offering Relic’s in-game description reads, “Changes ‘Fight’ into ‘X Fight’”. Functionally, this is true; if an Offering-adorned party member Fights, they will attack random enemies four times. However, the command menu will still say “Fight” instead of “X Fight”. This patch remedies this.

game.name: 2769 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: Super Mario Land 3: Tatanga’s Return is the author’s attempt at creating a “true” third Super Mario Land game, i.e. a game where the player actually controls Mario. As such, this hack is pretty much a traditional Mario game with a simple plot that takes a backseat to stomping on heads. This hack contains 60 levels spread across 7 Worlds.

game.name: 278 - F-Zero (USA)
game.info: This is a simple hack that allows you to race on tracks that would otherwise be available in Grandprix only. All 15 tracks are available without the full grid. Best times work as normal. To be used on a USA rom.

game.name: 2782 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: After a ship capsizes treasure is spilled into the sea. Help Cheep grab 50 pieces of treasure. It’s Dangerous to go alone and Cheep can’t stay in any one area to long. Use the X button to perform a Dash Attack. Use the L or R button to save the treasure and return to the overworld. If you die you will restart at the last pipe you exited, but it if you get game over or use LR save system you will be brought back to cheeps home. Some Graphics are drawn by awesomezac(not me) and Valterri of MFGG.

game.name: 2783 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: There are two events in the game that do not properly account for the possibility that Gau is on the Veldt. One of those events is the party selection at Zozo after getting the first Magicite, and the other is the return to Zozo after the Magitek Research Facility caper. The anomaly with the first event means that your remaining party members will not go to Narshe, meaning you cannot swap out with them until you have the airship; however, the second anomaly prevents this from happening because after the Esper World flashback, one of your party members will be positioned where Terra is supposed to get off the bed, meaning the game cannot advance. This patch corrects both events.

game.name: 2784 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The Phoenix Cave and Kefka’s Tower are two dungeons with a unique feature: you have to split into multiple parties when you enter them. These dungeons also have Save Points within them; when a party steps onto a Save Point, you can Save your game. However, try switching to another party and you’ll notice you still have the ability to Save, regardless of whether or not that party is on a Save Point. Not only that, but they can also use Tents and Sleeping Bags. This patch adds a Save Point check to the party switching function.

game.name: 2785 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The chest at the end of the Phoenix Cave is automatically opened by Locke when you reach the end; it contains the Phoenix Magicite. If you go back to that spot later, you’ll find that the chest has somehow been closed again, and you cannot reopen it. For the sake of continuity, this patch makes that chest stay open.

game.name: 2786 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: Certain spells, such as Haste and Doom, use the target’s sprite as one of the animation layers. There’s an interesting problem that occurs when one of these spells is reflected off an enemy onto one of your characters: that character will be forced to face the same direction as that enemy, even if that means getting turned around. This patch makes them face forward in this scenario.

game.name: 2787 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The Zombie status makes a character’s HP drop to 0 and can only be removed via Revivify, which also restores some HP. The Petrify status makes it impossible for a character to be damaged or healed. When you combine the two, you have the potential for a character to wind up with 0 HP, yet still alive and able to fight. If you apply Revivify to a Zombie that is Petrified, the Zombie status will be removed, but no HP will be gained. This patch allows Revivify to bypass Petrify status if the character is also a Zombie.

game.name: 279 - Super Mario World 2 - Yoshi's Island (USA)
game.info: This simple hack gives the Yoshis the colors they had in the introduction and official artwork, namely the different boot colors and darker brown Yoshi.

game.name: 2797 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The Doom spell summons the Grim Reaper to take the target’s soul away, causing Instant Death. However, if that target is wearing Magitek Armor, the Reaper will somehow neglect to include the legs. With this patch, the Reaper will always take your entire sprite away, with legs.

game.name: 28 - Super Mario RPG - Legend of the Seven Stars (USA)
game.description: Super Mario RPG - Legend of the Seven Stars (USA)
game.info: An almost complete text hack of Super Mario RPG (the only text left unhacked is the enemies’ names and the menus). The entire storyline has been changed.

patch.name: Super Mario RPG - Legend of the Seven Stars (USA).ips

rom.name: Super Mario RPG - Legend of the Seven Stars (USA).sfc

game.name: 2804 - Hourai Gakuen no Bouken! - Tenkousei Scramble (Japan)
game.description: Hourai Gakuen no Bouken! - Tenkousei Scramble (Japan)
game.info: This is a simple fix for Hourai’s insane random encounter rate. Hourai has a default encounter rate so high that it both makes walking around irritating, and overlevels your party enormously. As a result, the game is both tedious and extremely easy, which is very sad because of how charming and creative this interesting take on the RPG genre is, and how much potential in the mechanics side is wasted when you’re so overleveled. Encounter chance is coded so strangely and inconsistently between area types that it’s likely a bug, but that’s conjecture.

patch.name: Hourai Gakuen no Bouken! - Tenkousei Scramble (Japan).ips

rom.name: Hourai Gakuen no Bouken! - Tenkousei Scramble (Japan).sfc

game.name: 2806 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: In the Equip and Relic menus, you have the option to switch characters by pressing the L, R or Select buttons. However, you do not have the ability to instantly switch between the two menus; you have to exit to the main menu. This patch adds this as a new feature; all you have to do is press the Y button.

game.name: 2807 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: After the Battle for the Frozen Esper, you are allowed to choose your own party members. If you choose Gau as the only member, you can then find Shadow in Kohlingen’s café and hire him into the party. If you then go to the Veldt and have Gau Leap, Shadow will be the only member. However, if you then return to Narshe, Shadow is programmed to leave as soon as you try to enter, thus leaving you with an empty party. If this happens, you will be forced to reset.

game.name: 2808 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The Rage and Dance commands are unique in that, by selecting them, the party member who performs them becomes autonomous until the battle ends or they die. However, neither command is allowed for Imps, so any Imp who tries either command will Fight instead. Despite this, that Imp will still become autonomous. The Rage command is worse off because any party member who tries to Rage should gain statuses and status immunities, but this will not happen if they are an Imp. This patch corrects Imp’s treatment of Dance and Rage by preventing autonomy.

game.name: 2810 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: If you’re like me, you cast Float on Shadow right before the battle with Atma Weapon (so he won’t be affected by the Quake spell). However, you may be shocked to discover that when you eventually find him in the Dragon’s Neck Colosseum, he’s still Floating. That’s because the game doesn’t remove any of the status effects he is given between the Floating Continent and the Colosseum. This patch makes the game removes those statuses after you wait for him.

game.name: 2813 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: Relm has the ability to Control enemies by equipping a Relic called the Fake Moustache. This Control is broken whenever either entity dies or the Controlled enemy gets physically attacked; however, there are several ways in which one entity can be removed from the battle and the Control link will remain. This patch negates all of those ways and makes Control break when it should.

game.name: 2814 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: A character with the Condemned status will have a timer hanging over their head; when that timer reaches 0, the character dies. This can be prevented using the Safety Bit Relic, which will make the death procedure fail; however, if this happens, the character will still have Condemned status. This patch ensures that it gets removed.

game.name: 2815 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: If an enemy gains Zombie status, the game handles it by showing the normal death animation and making the enemy untargetable, as though it died. However, like Zombified characters, they are still able to attack targets on the field. This may confuse players in the sense that a Zombified enemy that has somehow become invisible is attacking them. This patch will stop all attacks from Zombified enemies.

game.name: 2816 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: If Life 3 gets cast on an Undead enemy, it will not usually revive them because Undead enemies do not get revived by Life spells; they get killed by them. However, Undead enemies do automatically revive themselves when struck by weapons that kill with an “X” animation. Then Life 3 would kick in, even though the enemy is still technically alive, and kill them. This patch exempts all Undead enemies from any effects of Life 3 spells.

game.name: 2817 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The Lore known as Rippler has the unique ability of swapping the statuses of the caster with the target. Unfortunately, it swaps too many statuses, including Terra’s Morph and Shadow’s Dog Block, which would be lost permanently. In addition, it swaps Zombie status, but does nothing to restore the HP of the entity that loses Zombie status, leaving you with a living character that has 0 HP. This patch incorporates Terii Senshi’s patch to fix the “too many statuses” issue, and combines it with one of three different algorithms (your choice) to restore HP to the former Zombie.

game.name: 2818 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: When you fight Wrexsoul, he always starts by casting Zinger to hide within one of your characters. While he does this, he is technically outside of the battle; to prevent the battle from ending immediately, he is accompanied by two Soul Saver enemies that harass you to death until the possessed party member dies. The problem is, the Soul Savers are vulnerable to Instant Death attacks, and even though they always revive themselves automatically, if they are killed simultaneously using the X-Zone spell, their revival will be delayed long enough for the game to consider the battle over, giving you an easy victory. This game prevents this possibility in one of two ways: you can make the Soul Savers immune to Instant Death, or you can prevent the game from giving you a victory as long as Zinger is active.

game.name: 2819 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The game’s damage algorithm has two major flaws. First, overflow. While calculating damage, the game stores the calculations in a 16-bit value, which caps off at 65,535. However, if a physical or magical attack would deal more than that, it will instead deal that amount MOD 65,536! In other words, 65,536 damage becomes 0! The physical damage algorithm has another flaw: the Genji Glove and Offering relics reduce all physical damage, regardless of whether or not the attacker’s weapon is involved. This patch does two things: one, it fixes the overflow problem for both types of damage, and two, it ensures the Genji Glove and Offering relics only reduce physical damage dealt by weapons.

game.name: 2820 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: One of the spells that Mog can cast through Dance is Tapir. It can only be cast by the Love Sonata, with a 1-in-16 chance. Tapir removes numerous status ailments from the party, one of which is Zombie. However, a Zombified party member will receive no healing, leaving them alive with 0 HP. This patch contains a choice of two algorithms to heal some HP in this scenario.

game.name: 2821 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: There are two places in the game where enemies can be flipped horizontally at the wrong time. One such place is when Sabin Suplexes a Muddled enemy. Another is when Rippler is cast on a Muddled enemy. In the latter case, the enemy will be extremely indecisive on which way it should be facing. This patch keeps everything in line in these two cases.

game.name: 2822 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The Offering relic is supposed to cut damage in half from all weapons, but it does not do so with Setzer’s Dice. This patch will, in the words of Jean-Luc Picard, “make it so”.

game.name: 2824 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: Living party members can use shields they have equipped to block incoming physical or magical attacks. They can also block Fenix Downs, but they will do so twice. This patch stops them from blocking Fenix Downs more than once.

game.name: 2826 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The SrBehemoth and FlameEater bosses are two enemies in the game that counter certain spells used against them. However, if another command such as Fight is used afterwards, they will counter that too, until another spell is used. This patch ensures that only the specified spells will be countered, and nothing else.

game.name: 2827 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: Apparently the Dragon’s Neck Colosseum feeds its Tyrannosaurs Folgers between battles, because they tend to get a bit jumpy. It’s especially noticeable when they are subject to the Haste or Slow spells, as they will actually jump back a bit during the spell’s animation, then jump forward again when it’s over. This patch forces the Colosseum staff to cut back on the caffeine.

game.name: 2828 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The game gives party members Near Fatal status whenever their HP is less than 1/8 of their max HP, with one exception: right after they’ve lost Petrify status. This patch eliminates that exception.

game.name: 2830 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The Imp status is a lot of things. It’s a bummer because it cancels out most commands, such as Tools and Blitz. It’s inconvenient because it nulls out all spells except Imp, which you can use to remove the status. It is also unfair because if you’re attempting to Summon an Esper, which you can only do once per Esper per battle, and you get turned into an Imp, not only do you fail to Summon the Esper, but you can no longer Summon it later in the battle. This patch eliminates this unfairness.

game.name: 2831 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The Wound, Petrify and Zombie statuses are considered to be the game’s “lethal” statuses. Whenever certain enemies are subject to them, they may perform a “final attack” before disappearing. However, in the case of Petrify, they will then perform an encore of their final attack after every turn. This patch puts a “limit one” on Petrified enemies’ final attacks.

game.name: 2834 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: This patch fixes the following ten erroneous events:

game.name: 2842 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: When characters have their equipment removed due to scripted events (e.g. the guy that allows you to remove equipment automatically from various party members all at once), the game does not recalculate that character’s stats, such as HP and MP. This means that those stats will be displayed wrong the next time you decide to change party members. This patch makes those events recalculate the stats automagically.

game.name: 2843 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The secret cave door in Narshe can be opened from the outside. If you do this in the World of Ruin, then open the main menu and then return, the door will reclose itself and you cannot reopen it unless you leave and come back. It does not reclose itself in the World of Balance. This patch makes the door stay open in both worlds.

game.name: 2844 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: When you face Phunbaba for the second time, if your party consists of only one party member, and that party member’s attack that triggers Phunbaba’s BabaBreath also kills him/her, he/she will be blown out of the party, leaving the party empty and leading to a crash.

game.name: 2845 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The game has a special sprite for monsters that have been turned into Imps; however, it does not use it correctly in numerous places. All switching of a monster’s sprite with the Imp sprite is achieved via the Imp spell, which not only means that some monsters that receive Imp status (e.g. via Rippler) won’t look like Imps, but also that some monsters will look like Imps when they don’t actually have Imp status. This patch makes all usage of the Imp sprite automatic.

game.name: 2846 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: When Terra’s Morph supply runs out, the game queues up the Revert command automatically to remove her Morph status. However, if she is Stopped, asleep or frozen when the gauge runs out, or if someone else is using Quick, she will not Revert. Also, if she leaves battle for any reason while Morphed, her Morph supply will still continue to deplete. This patch fixes both of these issues simultaneously.

game.name: 2851 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The Offering relic is supposed to cut damage inflicted by weapons in half. While this is true in most cases, the ValiantKnife is an exception. The damage inflicted by the weapon itself is halved, but the bonus damage it inflicts, which is equal to the difference between the attacker’s maximum HP and their current HP, is not. This patch makes sure the bonus damage is halved when Offering is equipped.

game.name: 2856 - Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.description: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.info: A modification for The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past that changes the main character to Cornelius from Odin Sphere. It also swaps tunics out for rings from the first Zelda title, and alters some of the game text to go with these changes.

patch.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).ips

rom.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).sfc

game.name: 2860 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: There is a hook outside the entrance to the Phoenix Cave which either of your two parties can use to exit and return to the airship. However, if you mistime the jump to the hook, your character will wind up on the pulley above it. This patch ensures that there are no timing issues.

game.name: 2861 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: Before you begin fighting MagiMaster atop the Fanatics’ Tower, your party is supposed to slowly turn to face him. However, this only works properly if your party is either facing down or to the right; otherwise, the party will turn in another direction before facing him. This patch ensures that your party always turns correctly regardless of what direction they are facing.

game.name: 2874 - Super Castlevania IV (USA)
game.info: This is a hack which changes the HUD and font to match that of Castlevania 1 & 3. The palette was also changed for the font.

game.name: 2878 - Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.description: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.info: This patch modifies the Bomb and Arrow counters to allow a maximum of 99 for both. It also allows the fairy to properly refund your rupees when you toss over 100 into the pond and try to upgrade something that is already maxed out.

patch.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).ips

rom.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).sfc

game.name: 2879 - Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.description: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.info: This patch allows you to use the L & R buttons to switch items in A Link to the Past. Complete with sound!

patch.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).ips

rom.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).sfc

game.name: 2880 - Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.description: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.info: Ancient Stone Tablets-style dashing in A Link to the Past!

patch.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).ips

rom.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).sfc

game.name: 2882 - Earth Defense Force (USA)
game.info: This is a small hack for the SNES game Super Earth Defense Force to drop the volume of a couple sound effects. Specifically, the “enemy taking damage” sound effect has been dropped considerably, and the “enemy death” sound has been dropped slightly.

game.name: 2884 - Super Castlevania IV (USA)
game.info: This is a hack of Super Castlevania IV. It changes the HUD and font to be similar to the first Castlevania game. Simons sprite was also recolored to be a simpler color palette like the one in the first game. Weapon and item sprites were also ported and in some cases re-shaded. There is also a special edit to the final form of Dracula also.

game.name: 2885 - Mortal Kombat (USA)
game.info: A simple hack that replaces the censored grey colors with a red blood spray.

game.name: 2893 - Super Ghouls'n Ghosts (USA)
game.info: This is a hack that changes various gameplay mechanics for Arthur including:

game.name: 2901 - Actraiser 2 (Europe) (En,Fr,De)
2902 - Mega Man 7 (USA)
game.info: Remove famous boss door bug in Spring man/Cloud man/Freeze man (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XRUDZOPJyeQ), enable all 8 robot masters with minor changes in AI except Slash man and Willy machine. The purpose of the patch is to make other bosses as difficult as slash man and willy, preventing them from being predictable.

game.name: 2903 - Dragon View (USA)
game.info: Changes the bosses status, making them more efficient and allows the bow shoot multiple arrows.

game.name: 291 - Super Metroid (Japan, USA) (En,Ja)
game.info: This is a mod in which the enemies have double HP. Except for Metroids and Ridley of course, they have WAY more than double. Many enemies also deal more damage! This is for the die-hard gamer. If you want me to make an even HARDER version, e-mail me at jtritter96@yahoo.com.

game.name: 2913 - Secret of Mana (USA)
game.info: Description: Simple patch that shrinks the “deadzone” that the player can freely walk in before the screen scrolls. This allows the screen to scroll sooner, so you aren’t right on top of enemies when they appear on screen. May cause minor graphics issues in areas with wrapping backgrounds.

game.name: 2919 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: Super Mario World Redrawn was released by icegoom as a graphics replacement pack. It requires Lunar Magic to re-insert the new graphical data and is geared towards anyone starting work on a Super Mario World hack who wants a complete and stylistically consistent sprite-set. Be sure to check it out over at SMW Central. The pack contains some other goodies as well.

game.name: 2926 - Final Fantasy II (USA) (Rev 1)
game.info: This romhack is a redesign of the original Final Fantasy IV game, focusing mostly on a revamped story and rebalanced gameplay. A lot of development time went into ensuring that the game was challenging and engaging to all playstyles.

game.name: 2930 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: A Captain Toad treasure tracker styled game for the snes. Credits are enclosed.

game.name: 2939 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: This hack was inspired by Chaos CompleXX by FPI, and is supposed to be everything wrong with a beginner hack, with it’s horrid palettes, blatant level edits, and awful use of grammar. In other words, don’t take this hack seriously.

game.name: 294 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: Final Fantasy 3 Eviltype is a patch of Final Fantasy 3 designed to completely rebalance the overall game, in such a way that it is as hard as reasonably possible without making it impossible for a theoretical newcomer to the game to still complete without unbelievable amounts of effort.

game.name: 2942 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: The sequel to the first Da Hak game. Like the first one, it has awful palettes, bad grammar, blatant edits, and cutoff. This one has some adult content in it so approach with caution.

game.name: 2943 - Rockman X (Japan)
game.info: In celebration of the New Year (2016), Puresabe made a ROM hack for Rockman X which changes the game into a one-on-one battle against Spark Mandrill (2016 is the Year of the Monkey according to the Chinese lunar calendar).

game.name: 2946 - Super Mario Kart (Japan)
game.info: Here is a patch which replaces the lives counter with a speedometer.

game.name: 2963 - Super Castlevania IV (USA)
game.info: Super Castlevania IV - No Candles Mod

game.name: 2989 - Super Metroid (Japan, USA) (En,Ja)
game.info: Here is a mini-hack for Super Metroid which you must escape from the the nightmare in which Samus is trapped in.

game.name: 2993 - Super Metroid (Japan, USA) (En,Ja)
game.info: Here is a patch which changes the colors and looks of all the space pirate enemies encountered to make them more distinguishable.

game.name: 2994 - Super Metroid (Japan, USA) (En,Ja)
game.info: Here is a patch which changes the appearance of the shutter lock, which can be used for those making a custom hack.

game.name: 2995 - Super Metroid (Japan, USA) (En,Ja)
game.info: Here are 2 patches which give new types of doors you can use for a custom hack.

game.name: 3007 - Super Mario All-Stars + Super Mario World (USA)
game.description: Super Mario All-Stars + Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: This hack reverts the title screen back to the color scheme of the original release. There are 3 variations for you to choose from:

patch.name: Super Mario All-Stars + Super Mario World (USA).bps

rom.name: Super Mario All-Stars + Super Mario World (USA).sfc

game.name: 3031 - Sanrio World Smash Ball! (Japan)
game.info: This improvement hack was made to expand some of the basic competitive features of the game and make it more convenient for playing against friends or otherwise. Major improvement features include:

game.name: 3041 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: Kamek has cast a magical spell on the Mushroom Kingdom, turning it into a strange new land. Join Mario on a brand new adventure as he conquers each task an order to break the spell and return the land back to normal.

game.name: 3042 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: After stopping the alien duo known as Hunter and Scorpion from ending the world via the Furnace, an alien doomsday device which was constructed in the center of their crash landing site, the Mushroom Kingdom rebuilt.

game.name: 3043 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: This a compilation of the levels from the 2008 Vanilla Level Design Contest (VLDC)

game.name: 3045 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: After two years of work it’s finally finished!! Classic Mario World 3:The finale is the sequel of Classic Mario World 2 and the final part of the CMW trilogy. Princess Rosalina’s observatory has been attacked by Bowser who want use the Power of the Power Stars with the Fragments from the Magical Crystals to become invincible,help Mario to find the Shiny Stars to defeat the Evil King Koopa.

game.name: 3046 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: A fairy simple Mario game. The game has a variety of custom sprites, music and blocks. The final update: some misc skips and related things.

game.name: 3047 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: This is a crossover hack featuring Mario Series, Megaman series and Bomberman series.

game.name: 3054 - Super Donkey Kong 2 - Dixie & Diddy (Japan)
game.info: Here is a ROM hack which changes all the levels up to stage 6-4 to different ones that are much harder to traverse.

game.name: 3057 - Kirby Bowl (Japan)
game.info: Greetings Grumps!

game.name: 3061 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: Super Mario Hack was made as a side project from Mario’s Final Quest. This hack focus was to make levels where each level has a completely different gimmick, using only resources found on the Central.

game.name: 3066 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: If you press Y immediately after pressing X, in a dungeon where you are split into multiple parties, the game will switch to the next party and then immediately open the Main Menu. Also, when you exit the Main Menu, you are able to move during the fade-in sequence, and in some cases you can even walk through NPCs.

game.name: 3079 - Home Improvement - Power Tool Pursuit! (USA)
game.info: This is a hack called Home Improvement: More Power! Edition. It makes the controls more sane, slows down the timer, makes continues infinite, and (debatably) makes the game more awesome by allowing Tim Taylor to continue firing his weapon during cutscenes.

game.name: 3085 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: During the scene where Sabin sneaks into the Imperial Camp at Doma, if you bring Shadow along with you, there may be times when the game mixes up the order of Sabin and Shadow in the party. This generally happens after the scenes featuring Cyan. This patch ensures that the order of the party members is always preserved.

game.name: 3086 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: If you face Shadow in the Colosseum and select Gogo as the opponent, Gogo may potentially Mimic Shadow’s commands. Even though Shadow is technically a character, he’s acting as Gogo’s enemy in this battle, and Mimic is not supposed to work on commands used by enemies. This patch makes Mimic ignore commands used by characters in the enemy formation.

game.name: 3088 - Mega Man 7 (USA)
game.info: This patch adds support for CD quality audio to Megaman 7 and Rockman 7 using MSU-1 chip invented by byuu. So far, it is only supported and tested on bsnes, higan and the SD2SNES flashcart.

game.name: 3101 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: When you go into Gogo’s Status menu to select his battle commands, the list of commands you can choose from does not account for the Relics he has equipped. FakeMustache, for example, changes “Slot” into “Control”; this changes is displayed everywhere except the command selection list. This patch keeps the list up to speed with Gogo’s equipped Relics.

game.name: 3136 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: There are many cases in the game where certain statuses won’t be displayed in battle. For example, a Poisoned, Magitek-riding character won’t have Poison status displayed. This is because Magitek status takes display precedence over Poison, but Magitek’s display name is blank. This patch ensures that blank display names do not override displaying other statuses.

game.name: 3137 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: Objects RAM ($0867-$1068) is not initialized on game reset. This can lead to a bug where characters x and y positions ($1FD3-$1FF2) loaded from the save file can be overwritten after save file loading by the objects x and y position RAM values.

game.name: 3147 - Chrono Trigger (USA)
game.info: This patch is geared towards fixing bugs and patching up script inconsistencies or censorship. The aim is to preserve the original translation while generally improving the game as a whole.

game.name: 3148 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: This patch brings back the Button Settings menu, which had been removed during localization. In an effort to avoid taking up any additional memory, the patch first rewrites an existing code section in a more compact way, freeing up the space it needs.

game.name: 3151 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: Tritoch tail is missing a small piece when calling his summon. This is because its frame data ($D1C645-$D1C67A in FF3us) is missing a byte pair. The first byte of the pair is a X,Y position (xxxxyyyy) of the block in 16 pixels intervals. The second byte determines the block taken from the monster graphic (n) as well as whether it’s flipped horizontally (h) and/or vertically (v). Format of second byte is vhnnnnnn.

game.name: 3152 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The Cafe sign in Zozo battle background has five pixels that have palette color #00. Since this color is the transparent color, when triggering an animation that require a flash, those pixels will remain black.

game.name: 3153 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The chocobo in the WOB auction house has two portions of his sprite cut off by the two lady NPC standing behind him. This is because those NPC sprites have priority over the chocobo one.

game.name: 316 - Super Metroid (Japan, USA) (En,Ja)
game.info: This hack will bring Super Metroid (and even general video-gaming) into a absolute, never experienced before, new level of difficulty. Everybody who thinks Super Metroid is easy, will find the perfect solution with this hack. Most rooms are designed to be harder to pass, the entire route is changed to make you feel like literally going through hell, and the Bosses are so hard, that you will only get a minimal chance to win!

game.name: 3166 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: This patch corrects two small, rather hard to notice graphical issues with the Sealed Gate battle background, where two small sections of the bridge were seemingly colored in wrong.

game.name: 3167 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: When you first enter the Thamasa map (157) from the boat ride, and then also again on the other Thamasa map (154) after Kefka attacks, for the first time, without moving forward right away, your character will be in the ready position facing downward due to the 3B command being set in the previous code. This patch simply removes both cases of the command and fixes the issue to normal.

game.name: 3172 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The cultists living at the Fanatics’ Tower seem to be psychic; if you try to steal the Gem Box from the top, they will be on you pretty quickly. However, these “psychics” aren’t perfect; they cannot foresee the possibility that you just stand in front of the chest but don’t open it. They will still come up to you and demand that you return the treasure. This patch ensures that you will not be punished for a crime you didn’t commit.

game.name: 3173 - Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.description: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.info: Have you ever wondered, how smart you are? Time to test it out with this unconventional Zelda hack, which will test the limits of your intuitive and logical thinking.

patch.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).ips

rom.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).sfc

game.name: 3175 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: After you follow “Gerad” to Figaro’s basement, he reveals himself as Edgar and then quick-changes into his kingly garb before you fight the Tentacles in the engine room. After the fight, he will then quick-change back into his Gerad disguise for some reason. This is a continuity error that is remedied by this patch, which stops Edgar from changing at all until after the other thieves leave.

game.name: 3183 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: This hack implement a music player available from the Main menu or Config menu. This code is heavily based from FF6-T Edition implementation of the music player which used the same idea as Pandora’s Box in terms of menu layout and maybe actual coding.

game.name: 3192 - Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.description: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.info: Do you believe the original IQ test hack to be too difficult, than this is the game for you. The remodel slightly remakes the original IQ test hack, with the purpose to change the puzzles from difficult to medium. Now every average player should be able to finish the game.

patch.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).ips

rom.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).sfc

game.name: 3197 - Mega Man X (USA) (Rev 1)
game.info: Have you ever wanted to play as X without any armor enhancements, but still have the abilities of them? Well, it’s now possible in this hack. This hack removes all of X’s armor graphics and includes some new ones for the hadouken and reduced damage animations along with the ending cut-scene as well.

game.name: 3203 - Tetris Battle Gaiden (Japan)
game.info: Enables you to play as the bosses right at the character selection screen in Story mode or VS mode.

game.name: 3215 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: Shadow can sometimes get cold feet, like when he’s preparing to Throw at a target, but suddenly the target isn’t there because they Jumped, and there are no other applicable targets to Throw at. This intimidates him to the point that instead of stepping forward to throw, he’ll simply step back. Do this enough times and he’ll eventually hide off the edge of the screen like Edward from Final Fantasy IV. This patch makes Shadow step up every time.

game.name: 3216 - Final Fantasy V (Japan)
game.info: When you kill an enemy, it dies using the slowest animation possible: a two-second long dissolve. Since the GBA version’s dissolve animation is much faster, this patch makes the SNES dissolve fast also.

game.name: 3219 - Final Fantasy V (Japan)
game.info: After the Barrier Tower explodes, Galuf waits to see if Xezat made it out. The rest of your party reforms…and if Galuf was the leader, you’ll see two Galufs on the screen. This patch ensures that the leader sprite is properly updated in this particular event.

game.name: 3221 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: This modification showing mountain ranges on both mini-maps was originally applied in the now obsolete FF3Edit editor when you save the ROM. Since those new mini-maps take more space, WOR mini-map was stored at F0/0000 when saving. With the patch, all subsequent compressed graphics after WOB mini-map are shifted and some of the EF/FBC8 free space is used instead.

game.name: 3229 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: When you go to visit the Narshe weapons salesman, he shows you a piece of Magicite - Ragnarok. But he’s trying to show it to you and NOT your character, as evidenced by the fact that if your character is approaching him from the south, the Magicite will appear behind his or her head. This patch makes the salesman keep the stone close to him until he actually gives it to you.

game.name: 3232 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: This patch implement a selectable GBA Font in Config menu. The only free space it use is less than $D0 bytes at end of bank $C3 for actual menu work. Otherwise, functions have been optimized or at least shortened in order to fit in the new code, especially in bank $C0.

game.name: 3233 - Mega Man X (USA)
game.info: This hack for Mega Man X changes all the levels and graphics from the original into a whole new layout. The background music are also changed.

game.name: 3236 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: In the Super Famicom version of Final Fantasy VI, the player can rename Cyan’s sword techniques from the main menu. Given that the expanded names would not fit into the area of save data memory reserved for them, this feature was removed during localization.

game.name: 3238 - Super Mario All-Stars (USA)
game.info: These patches fix Lakitu’s Spiny Egg throwing behavior just like the patches for SMB1 NES and SMB2J but now work in All-Stars! Fixes both SMB1 and Lost Levels, now updated for all regions!

game.name: 3239 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: When you enter the Opera House from the World Map, the organ ragtime background music in the lobby plays too loudly. It’s supposed to be muffled in the lobby and normal in the theatre, but entering from the World Map, you can hear that it’s normal in the lobby. This patch adds an event trigger at the entrance that quiets the music down while removing an event trigger from Kefka’s Tower that allows party 3 to grab an invisible hook.

game.name: 3240 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: When Terra is opening the Sealed Gate and your party has to face Kefka to buy time, Kefka has a chance of using a special attack. The problem is, it’s not really that special. It’s so not-special that it always misses. It’s so not-special that it has no animation. In fact, it’s so not-special that it apparently doesn’t even have a name. So when he uses it, all you’ll see at the top of the screen is a blank window. This patch causes Special attacks used by characters to load correctly so this doesn’t happen.

game.name: 3246 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: The 9th Annual Vanilla Level Design Contest Collab Hack of 2016 features 108 contest submissions, along with various staff, judge, and post-game levels. There are a total of 152 exits spread across 117 levels.

game.name: 3247 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: “When you first reach Terra in Zozo, she’s laying in bed with her eyes open. Then during the conversation with Ramuh, she thrashes around, and the party helps her back into bed to recuperate, with her eyes now closed. However, should you leave the room and re-enter, even before getting the Magicite or talking to your comrades, her eyes will be open again. This despite her being equally unresponsive when talked to and the party’s dialogue not changing.”

game.name: 3252 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: Party members can wear the True Knight relic, and it’ll allow them to shield allies who are Near Fatal from attacks. If the attack misses, the guarding party member will be incorrectly drawn under or over neighboring allies when they return to the line-up. This patch ensures that they will be drawn correctly.

game.name: 3259 - Rockman X (Japan)
game.info: In celebration of the New Year (2017), Puresabe made a ROM hack for Rockman X which changes the game into a one-on-one battle against Storm Eagle (2017 is the Year of the Rooster according to the Chinese lunar calendar, however, Storm Eagle is a close relative).

game.name: 3260 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: If you try to leave Narshe during the opening assault, Terra will be shown as the party leader even if she isn’t. The same will also happen when arriving at the mine and knocking down the gate to the Esper. Also, if your party triggers a battle while not facing forward, they will not face forward while being attacked. In addition, Terra does not face the right way when you try to leave Narshe with either Vicks or Wedge leading the party. Furthermore, the supposedly-mandatory two-wave fight right before the pincer attack is actually skippable. These are all problems that this patch fixes.

game.name: 3262 - Super Mario RPG - Legend of the Seven Stars (USA)
game.description: Super Mario RPG - Legend of the Seven Stars (USA)
game.info: In December 2016, a user by the name of NightBlader made a great hack called Super Mario RPG Plus. Many changes were made to personal taste based off of the original work. Several of the author’s original ideas have been left implemented. To distinguish this hack from the original there are many gameplay changes, since the original author wanted only a vanilla+ hack, he scrapped the gameplay changes. Many names of monsters and items were changed and added/deviated from the original hack. There are new FP costs, Specials learned at different levels, level up stat changes, and level up bonuses changed. Some changes are reverted. Graphics are even changed up a bit. Please enjoy this hack!

patch.name: Super Mario RPG - Legend of the Seven Stars (USA).bps

rom.name: Super Mario RPG - Legend of the Seven Stars (USA).sfc

game.name: 3295 - Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.description: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.info: The final installment of the IQ series, The Revenge of the Einstein, includes some of the most difficult block puzzles ever created in a Zelda game. The already existing puzzles from the IQ and Conker, which were considered to be of a better design, were used in this game and remodeled to be even more difficult, yet some rare puzzles are brand new.

patch.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).ips

rom.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).sfc

game.name: 3301 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: Sabin’s Blitz menu shows the input codes and descriptions of all Blitz techniques he has learned; however, it does not show their names. If you want to see their names, you’ll have to either use them in battle or apply this patch.

game.name: 3313 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: In Kefka’s Tower or the Phoenix Cave, if you hold Y as you step onto a tile with an event trigger, the game will switch parties without triggering the event. If you switch back to that party, the event will trigger then. This patch ensures that the Y button does not delay event triggers.

game.name: 3320 - Super Metroid (Japan, USA) (En,Ja)
game.info: Super Metroid: Zebes Revisited was inspired by Super Metroid: Zebes Returns and changes the item order of the game (you start by collecting power bombs instead of missiles).

game.name: 3321 - Tetris & Dr. Mario (USA)
game.info: Dr. Mario SNES - disables the punishment blocks any time a 2+ combo is matched.

game.name: 3336 - Mega Man 7 (USA)
game.info: Have you ever noticed how completely useless the Mega Buster is in Mega Man 7? How about the really short invulnerability period Megaman has after being injured? Have you ever wished someone would come along and do something about it? Well, you’re in luck because someone finally has!

game.name: 3339 - Super Ghouls'n Ghosts (USA)
game.info: Super Ghouls and Ghosts Practice ROM patch

game.name: 3340 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: There are two doors in the game that are hidden, revealed only by activating the right event. One is in the clock room in the rich man’s basement in South Figaro, and the other is in the Fanatics’ Tower. The problem is, these two maps can go glitchy if you open the door, enter the Main Menu and then leave; you’ll see a bunch of wrong tiles in the vicinity of the door. This patch corrects this behaviour. It also corrects the issue of open doors in the Fanatics’ Tower not being fully opaque, meaning you can see clouds behind the openings in the doors even though the doorways lead to closed rooms. The readme lists a few other wrong tile errors on various maps.

game.name: 3341 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: Odds are, you’ll eventually encounter the White Dragon in the Fanatics’ Tower. When this happens, the camera will move to your position before the fight starts. The only way to make it move back to where it was is to leave the room and then re-enter. This patch ensures the camera will not move in the first place.

game.name: 3346 - Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.description: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.info: Initially built as a spiritual sequel to Parallel Worlds, this project has evolved so much overtime that eventually it became an unofficial sequel to an M Rated game that was released late in the Nintendo 64 lifespan, none other than Conker’s Bad Fur Day!

patch.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).ips

rom.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).sfc

game.name: 3348 - Donkey Kong Country 3 - Dixie Kong's Double Trouble! (USA) (En,Fr)
game.description: Donkey Kong Country 3 - Dixie Kong's Double Trouble! (USA) (En,Fr)
game.info: This fixes Kiddy’s color palette in bonus screens when the COLOR cheat is used. Specifically, in the retail game, Dixie’s color palette was properly adjusted to dark purple, but Kiddy’s is still blue. This hack makes Kiddy’s palette green as it should be. This change was backported from Japanese v1.1, the only known revision that assigns Kiddy’s color palette properly.

patch.name: Donkey Kong Country 3 - Dixie Kong's Double Trouble! (USA) (En,Fr).ips

rom.name: Donkey Kong Country 3 - Dixie Kong's Double Trouble! (USA) (En,Fr).sfc

game.name: 3387 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: This patch correct the bug where Shadow could be seen in South Figaro but not in the pub after you have beat Vargas. There is an additional check for the “Vargas is beaten” bit made in South Figaro entrance event. See readme for more details.

game.name: 3389 - Firemen, The (Europe) (En,Fr,De)
game.info: This Patch change the region of The Firemen PAL/EUROPE to NTSC/USA so it can be played at 60Hz.

game.name: 3402 - Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.description: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.info: Did you know that there was a pseudo-sequel to A Link to the Past released six years after the original and exclusively on a broadcast satellite service in Japan? The maker of this hack did… and thought it would be fun to port the player characters from that game into this one.

patch.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).bps

rom.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).sfc

game.name: 3404 - Mega Man X3 (USA)
game.info: The author felt in Megaman X3 Zero looked like he spent the the whole day riding a horse, so this hack changes the graphics of his idle stance to make him look a little more like he did in X2

game.name: 3406 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: Super Mario Arcade, A bit of a mix of SMB,SMW, and NSMBDS.

game.name: 3409 - Mega Man X (USA) (Rev 1)
game.info: Megaman X Remix is a collection of patches for Megaman X that work together to provide a streamlined experience for veterans of the series. It is a series of small changes that allow you to approach the game in a new way.

game.name: 3412 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: Setzer has the ability to Summon random Espers at no MP cost: all you have to do is get three BARs using his Slot command. However, if he Summons Phoenix, he’ll end up one step forward from his usual position. If he Summons Palidor, he’ll end up one step backward. This patch ensures that he does not shift in either direction.

game.name: 3419 - Mega Man X (USA)
game.info: This hack updates the MMX- Generation game to start with leg capsules. This because the game already allows you to start with dash but doesn’t give you the leg sprites, so MM looks weird in the intro stages if you use dash.

game.name: 3428 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: The spell Roulette creates a rapidly moving finger pointer to select a target for auto-death. You’ll see it if Strago or Gogo casts it as a Lore, or if an enemy casts it; however, you will not see it if it is cast via Sketch or Rage. Furthermore, Roulette will never target party members. This patch makes the Roulette spell cast by Sketch or Rage identical to the version cast by enemies.

game.name: 3451 - Super Mario RPG - Legend of the Seven Stars (USA)
game.description: Super Mario RPG - Legend of the Seven Stars (USA)
game.info: This hack of Super Mario RPG makes the game more challenging and is meant for players who are experienced with the base game.

patch.name: Super Mario RPG - Legend of the Seven Stars (USA).ips

rom.name: Super Mario RPG - Legend of the Seven Stars (USA).sfc

game.name: 3461 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: This hack remove the gradient. There are two patches, one that removes it permanently, one that add a menu option on second config page to toggle the gradient.

game.name: 3465 - Fire Emblem - Seisen no Keifu (Japan)
game.info: This is a little of Fire Emblem: Seisen no Keifu. This hack is for the most part simple in nature, however, things are a bit different here in this fun little hack. As it says everyone and everything is greatly inflated to high levels! All the enemies are much stronger than they are in the original game as well as all player units. Nearly everyone enemies included have holy weapons! And that is the main focus of this so have fun!

game.name: 3470 - Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles IV - Turtles in Time (USA)
game.description: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles IV - Turtles in Time (USA)
game.info: This hack fixes up all the misspellings and typos in this game.

patch.name: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles IV - Turtles in Time (USA).ips

rom.name: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles IV - Turtles in Time (USA).sfc

game.name: 3473 - Super Ghouls'n Ghosts (USA)
game.info: This hack restores the crosses that appeared in the background and on the zombie’s coffin from the Japanese version back to the American version and it also changes the name of the final boss from Sardius back to Samael as well.

game.name: 3477 - Zombies Ate My Neighbors (USA)
game.info: Welcome to the toughest and most diabolical version of Zombies Ate my Neighbors yet! All 55 levels are completely re-made and are tougher than ever! How far can Zeke or Julie and the neighbors make it before the monsters take over?

game.name: 3478 - Mortal Kombat II (USA) (Rev 1)
game.info: This hack fixes three things to make the game more like its arcade counterpart:

game.name: 3479 - Zombies Ate My Neighbors (USA)
game.info: Welcome to Zombies Ate my Neighbors: Dr. Tongue’s Revenge where all 55 levels are once again re-made with some unique ideas! Although this hack is designed to be much more forgiving than the first two, don’t be deceived as Dr. Tongue is once again back and is determined to get revenge!

game.name: 3488 - NBA Jam - Tournament Edition (USA)
game.info: This patch fixes the glitches options for the hack NBA Jam 2k17.

game.name: 3493 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: The Luigi Version of Super Mario Arcade. It has physics very similar to smb2j’s Luigi.

game.name: 3496 - Smash Tennis (Europe)
game.info: This Patch change the region of Smash Tennis PAL/EUROPE to NTSC/USA so it can be played at 60Hz.

game.name: 3513 - Contra III - The Alien Wars (USA)
game.info: This hack restores the cheat codes, the unlimited continues and the ability to fight the secret final boss in Normal mode from the Japanese version of this game back to the American version of it.

game.name: 3564 - Mega Man X3 (USA)
game.info: This hack is an Addendum for Justin’s Zero Project 3.1.

game.name: 3566 - Final Fight 3 (USA)
game.info: This hack restores the original color palettes for all the enemies that got censored in the American version and it also restores Dean’s original first cutscene dialogue from the beta version as well.

game.name: 3572 - E.V.O. - Search for Eden (USA)
game.info: This hack decensors and fixes all the typos in the game’s script, it also restores the dinosaur droppings that only appeared in the Japanese version of the Domain of Brontosaurus stage as well.

game.name: 3573 - Mega Man X (USA)
game.info: Simply skips the introduction/highway stage and goes directly to the boss/stage select screen similar to classic NES Megaman.

game.name: 3576 - Arabian Nights - Sabaku no Seirei Ou (Japan)
game.description: Arabian Nights - Sabaku no Seirei Ou (Japan)
game.info: This patch adjust the timed random battles in something less abusive and unfair.

patch.name: Arabian Nights - Sabaku no Seirei Ou (Japan).ips

rom.name: Arabian Nights - Sabaku no Seirei Ou (Japan).sfc

game.name: 358 - Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.description: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.info: It’s a pretty stupid hack I did because I was bored and like nonsensical swearing and foul language.

patch.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).ips

rom.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).sfc

game.name: 3593 - Mega Man X2 (USA)
game.info: Simply skips the introduction/reploid factory stage and goes directly to the boss/stage select screen similar to classic NES Megaman.

game.name: 3594 - Mega Man X3 (USA)
game.info: Simply skips the introduction/hunter base stage and goes directly to the boss/stage select screen similar to classic NES Megaman.

game.name: 368 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: This is a hack that has you going through a min. of 100 rooms filled with enemies with an occasional power-up. At the end is a fake Bowser and a door leading to the final boss. All that in four levels! WOW!

game.name: 37 - Earth Bound - New Controls 1.0 by Herringway (Hack)
game.description: Earth Bound - New Controls 1.0 by Herringway (Hack)
game.info: In the words of its creator, “Arn’s Winter Quest has been a labor of love for me for two months, and rivals those hacks such as Hat Quest and EarthBound 2.5: Electric Boogaloo Joint Jive. It has a lot of fun inside jokes, an incoherent story, and all new battle graphics. This hack is basically linear Dragon Warrior with a bunch of humor thrown in, so if you like fighting and you like funny and you like very hard viewtiful fun time hacks, then don’t play this hack because it’ll satisfy your cravings and your head will probably explode.”

patch.name: Earth Bound - New Controls 1.0 by Herringway (Hack).ips

rom.name: Earth Bound - New Controls 1.0 by Herringway (Hack).smc

game.name: 372 - Lufia II - Rise of the Sinistrals (USA)
game.description: Lufia II - Rise of the Sinistrals (USA)
game.info: A patch that changes all occurences of “Arty” to “Artea” to match up with the dialogue.

patch.name: Lufia II - Rise of the Sinistrals (USA).ips

rom.name: Lufia II - Rise of the Sinistrals (USA).sfc

game.name: 376 - Tecmo Secret of the Stars (USA)
game.info: This fixes a small memory-initialization bug in the game. When speaking to this guard who requests 1000 Gold, the value actually deducted from the player’s account is random. While the buggy behavior is in the player’s benefit, I made a patch that restores the proper behavior. (with a tiny text change because I’m too lazy to repoint the message)

game.name: 386 - Final Fantasy II (USA)
game.info: Anyone who has played FFIV knows that Edward’s Medicine/Heal command is pretty useless, since it splits a Potion among 5 people. That’s like sharing a slice of pizza with your whole family — and who wants to do that? So I’ve created a patch that will increase the HP recovery done by this command, into the 60-90 HP range. Now everybody can have a slice.

game.name: 390 - Final Fantasy II (USA)
game.info: Because it’s so weak, FuSoYa’s Regen command in FFIV is not really worth using; it only restores 10 HP per phase, for a total heal of about 100 HP. At the point in the game where he joins your party, this is pretty pathetic. This patch increases the HP recovery of the command to 255 HP per phase, for a total heal of 2000-2500 HP.

game.name: 395 - Super Mario World 2 - Yoshi's Island (USA)
game.info: Story: The stork was peacefully on his way to deliver future heroes Baby Mario and Luigi to their parents, when all of a sudden, Kamek appeared in the skies. He quickly attempted to snatch the babies from the stork, only managing take Baby Luigi, while Baby Mario fell to the ocean. Luckily, he lands on Yoshi’s Island. The Yoshies gather and ponder how to remedy the situation. The Yoshies decide to carry along Baby Mario, and call upon the Chosen One to face Kamek. The Yoshies don’t know the exact identity of the Chosen One, but know that he always watches over and protects the Yoshies, and has an immense amount of power.

game.name: 404 - Might and Magic III - Isles of Terra (USA)
game.description: Might and Magic III - Isles of Terra (USA)
game.info: In the unpatched version of this game, the various shrines which should permanently increase the users Personality stat instead increase Intellect, although temporary effects, such as the well in A1 that increases Personality for a day, function normally.

patch.name: Might and Magic III - Isles of Terra (USA).ips

rom.name: Might and Magic III - Isles of Terra (USA).sfc

game.name: 405 - Super Metroid (Japan, USA) (En,Ja)
game.info: This small hack only changes the control setup for the game, to something closer to the newer GBA Metroid games. The opening Options menus have been altered to show the new controls for the game. Item pickup messages and Japanese text have not been altered however.

game.name: 41 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: Bowser is back again, more powerful than times ago: He was able to find a parallel Dimension and build up a big airship fleet in there because he plans a huge attack on Mario’s World. He also kidnapped the Princess one time more! A new incredible challenge for Mario and Yoshi!

game.name: 419 - Final Fantasy II (USA) (Rev 1)
game.info: I’m fairly certain anyone with even a mild interest in Final Fantasy IV knows that the Easy Type version, which was released in Japan at about the same time the US got its Final Fantasy II, has many interesting changes that aren’t present in any other version of the game. Nonetheless if you spend enough time on forums you will inevitably find people who use “Easy Type” and “Final Fantasy II” interchangeably, as if they were identical to one another, despite all the evidence to the contrary available via a quick search online.

game.name: 42 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: This is an easier version of the original Second Reality 1 Project. It’s called SNES-Version, because this one is definitely beatable, if you play it on a real SNES without savestates! The game for itself, it’s still hard, but absolutely possible to beat. A lot of things are changed in mostly every level to decrease the difficulty. Many more midway points have been added, gameplay is edited, some enemies are deleted, more power-ups are added, and so on. I’m sure you will notice some changes. Enjoy it! :D

game.name: 421 - 7th Saga, The (USA)
game.info: 7th Saga was a challenging and original RPG for SNES, but suffered from ridiculous difficulty and tedious level grinding. This hack attempts to address the difficulty so that the game is challenging without being frustrating, and to add a few fun elements to expand the strategy. Equipment and attack spells have been powered-up. More enemies have been given elemental weaknesses. New equipment and spells have been introduced. Additional changes are outlined in the readme.

game.name: 43 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: Hehe… this hack is probably the biggest bullshit hack ever made. It’s garbage! This hack is full with glitches, bad colour palettes, annoying and simple level designs, and a lot of message boxes with senseless and funny comments - very bad english included. Made as a spoof of the typical bad newbie hacks. Play it… and have fun… :D

game.name: 431 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: August 8, 2011 - Augmented version+!

game.name: 436 - Final Fantasy II (USA)
game.info: A text hack changing skill names, weapon, armor, item, spell, and other names. Slightly increased difficulty in some cases. Decreased slightly in others.

game.name: 440 - Final Fantasy II (USA)
game.info: This hacks the game’s dialogue text routine to support character-over-character DTE like the Japanese version uses in addition to FF2us’s normal English DTE and uses it to implement an 8×16 dialogue font. This patch works with either version of FF2us but will not display properly in accurate emulators or on an actual SNES console. The code used to create the patch is included in the readme.

game.name: 441 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: A quote from Master ZED’s Final Fantasy 3us/6j Glitches & Bugs guide describing the problem this fix corrects:

game.name: 448 - Final Fantasy II (USA)
game.info: This patch is really only for hackers. In the original game, spells are added to spell lists based on spell number. If you change spell effects, however (for example, changing a White spell to a Black spell), then the spell will still be added to a White list.

game.name: 458 - Tiny Toon Adventures - Buster Busts Loose! (USA)
game.description: Tiny Toon Adventures - Buster Busts Loose! (USA)
game.info: This patch will fix a single instance in the game where a custom control setting can kill the player.

patch.name: Tiny Toon Adventures - Buster Busts Loose! (USA).ips

rom.name: Tiny Toon Adventures - Buster Busts Loose! (USA).sfc

game.name: 46 - Final Fantasy IV (Japan) (Rev 1)
game.info: This ROM hack alters the game into a story mostly centered on characters from at least one other game in the Final Fantasy series, notably Celes and Terra.

game.name: 47 - Final Fantasy II (USA)
game.info: This patch will give Rydia a new command to replace her lost white magic when she matures: a random called monster that costs her no MP.

game.name: 475 - Final Fantasy II (USA)
game.info: For those of you that aren’t aware, Yang’s HP does not increase past level 60. It seems that someone goofed when putting in the information, so go figure. This patch is here to fix that behavior. The stats mirror that of FF4A (GBA) Euro version (or Jap 1.1 revision) of this game which has this fixed.

game.name: 477 - Super Metroid (Japan, USA) (En,Ja)
game.info: This is a (very) simple patch that makes it so Super Metroid’s missile (pink) doors open with a single missile, rather than five, like the ones in Metroid Zero Mission and the Metroid Prime series. I created it for myself as I prefer Zero Mission’s style, but I decided to release it publicly on the chance someone else wants to play with it. I recommend using this with Kejardon’s Control Freak patch, for an experience even closer to Zero Mission.

game.name: 48 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: This hack is worth playing simply due to its originality! Be warned however that some may find its content offensive. If you are not easily offended, it is hilarious with its use of violent imagery, such as the numerous squirming, bleeding Toads impaled on stakes in a graveyard as shown in the screenshots, not to mention that Morton’s Jail has to be the single most disturbing level ever created for a Mario game! There are also many drug references, a hidden evil Kirby world, and if you can find it, an Adults Only Palace of Hentai. This hack is very fun and is about the same level of difficulty as the original. It features awesome graphics rips, music and overall feel from Super Mario Bros 3, custom blocks, overworld and sprites. Even the credits have something interesting and unexpected in them! So, if you don’t have a problem with some morbid humor and twisted creativity, this is the game for you. Enjoy.

game.name: 481 - Final Fantasy II (USA)
game.info: Following in the footsteps of Dragonsbrethren’s Warp Animation hack (although I probably won’t reach the same heights), this hack was created to give some useful purpose to two useless battle spells, Sight and Dispel. Both spells now inflict status effects. These status effects are underrated and are also underused, and you should be able to have some use for them.

game.name: 482 - Final Fantasy II (USA)
game.info: For those of you that are curious, FF2 was shipped off to the US as an easier and toned down version of FF4. One of the changes made was to remove all existence of 3 White Magic spells, Protect, Shell, and Dispel. You can see Protect (known as Armor) and Shell when fighting the Mind monster in the Lunar Core. Shell is seen as a counter to Holy or Meteo on the Mind monster. There are only 4 weapons that cast these spells, and these changes will allow to see the effects of these spells. The spells were never removed from the game… they are merely hidden and the spells learned by level had changed.

game.name: 484 - Final Fantasy II (USA)
game.info: Other than documenting the location of Protect and Shell for the purpose of hacking, this should make these two spells a bit more impactful than before. Protect by default increases defense by 5. This has been increased to 10. Shell by default increases magic defense by 3. This has been increased to 8.

game.name: 485 - Final Fantasy II (USA)
game.info: There are a number of bits that were set, but went unused in FF4. I decided to make the unusable bits do something useful. Based on the bits set, the equipment were given the appropriate tweaks. The weapons that were changed are the following: Power Staff, Flame Whip, Wooden Hammer. I have also provided a patch for the GBA port, even though those hidden bits were removed from that version.

game.name: 489 - Ogre Battle - The March of the Black Queen (USA)
game.description: Ogre Battle - The March of the Black Queen (USA)
game.info: This hack offers tweaked stat growth and modified job trees. Dragoners/dragon masters are female, skeletons and ghosts can evolve, and, because the creator can’t change items yet, beast masters can use the dragos item to get a sex change.

patch.name: Ogre Battle - The March of the Black Queen (USA).ips

rom.name: Ogre Battle - The March of the Black Queen (USA).sfc

game.name: 49 - Super Mario World (USA)
game.info: A short yet sweet adventure from the perspective of one of those jumpy little guys from SMB2. Though its only 8 levels long, its still very fun, and the ASM and graphics are superb, similar in style to that of Super Mario Odyssey. It can be a challenge in areas, but is moderately easy as a whole. Worth checking out.

game.name: 490 - Ogre Battle - The March of the Black Queen (USA)
game.description: Ogre Battle - The March of the Black Queen (USA)
game.info: This patch moves Dragoners and Dragon Masters from the Fighter class tree to the Amazon class tree. Using a DRAGOS on a Beast Master will still change him into a Dragoner. Both classes also have different alignment, charisma, and minimum level requirements reflecting their status as sister classes to the Beast Man/Beast Master classes.

patch.name: Ogre Battle - The March of the Black Queen (USA).ips

rom.name: Ogre Battle - The March of the Black Queen (USA).sfc

game.name: 491 - Final Fantasy II (USA) (Rev 1)
game.info: This modifies the behavior of the spell subroutines used by Protect/Armor and Shell. Normally, spells using these subroutines increase the targets’ defense or magic defense by a constant amount. With this patch, however, the subroutines will instead cause the targets’ defense or magic defense to be increased by an amount equal to the spell’s power.

game.name: 492 - Final Fantasy III (USA)
game.info: This is the “Core Hack” meaning it’s not the whole game. What it is though is a large series of modifications I made to the game with help from other contributors which I’ll list in the credits below.

game.name: 493 - Final Fantasy V Spoof by Tzepish v1.01 [T+Eng1.1_RPGe]
game.description: Final Fantasy V Spoof by Tzepish v1.01 [T+Eng1.1_RPGe]
game.info: This is a comedy / parody hack of Final Fantasy 5. Unlike most other “spoofs” out there, I have taken every precaution necessary to make sure this spoof doesn’t end up filled with lame, juvenile humor.

patch.name: Final Fantasy V Spoof by Tzepish v1.01 [T+Eng1.1_RPGe].ips

rom.name: Final Fantasy V Spoof by Tzepish v1.01 [T+Eng1.1_RPGe].smc

game.name: 503 - Final Fantasy II (USA)
game.info: A number of changes were made to FF2US and FF4 Easytype to “dummy out” the existence of a number of White Magic spells from the original FF4 spell list.

game.description: BS Zelda no Densetsu - Adventuras de Pikachu - Map One (Hack)
game.info: This is the Restoration Map1 patch (complete) which purpose is to restore the original BS-X Gameplay of the game.

patch.name: BS Zelda no Densetsu - Adventuras de Pikachu - Map One (Hack).ips

rom.name: BS Zelda no Densetsu - Adventuras de Pikachu - Map One (Hack).smc

game.description: BS Zelda no Densetsu Remix - Map 2 - Dai-1-wa (Hack) (BS)
game.info: This is the Restoration Map2 patch (complete) which purpose is to restore the original BS-X Gameplay of the game.

rom.name: BS Zelda no Densetsu Remix - Map 2 - Dai-1-wa (Hack) (BS).smc

game.description: BS Zelda no Densetsu - Adventuras de Pikachu - Map Two (Hack)
game.info: This is the LOZ - Fourth Quest (complete) patch, which purpose is to transform BS Zelda into an old fashion Legend of Zelda game.
